utterances: My I word is not Iraq and not incumbent, but interesting.
You know, since the I-see-white-people McKinney - interesting, because she specialized in being outrageous.
But being outrageous is not enough.
Oh, Michael, just make your point.
So her not wearing her Congressional pin that fateful day seems to me to have been an omen on the Hill.
Lieberman, interesting.
Like Cynthia McKinney, these people really believe - these incumbents, these Congress people - really believe their own press clips.
This is a decision on Lieberman's part after the people decided, the Democrats decided.
That is arrogant and egotistical and selfish and shameless.
They think they're indispensable and they're not.
Voters gave him a message.
He's now ignoring the voters.
He's going to his traditional base, which his to be - to hope that people are still suffering from the middle-of-the-road-itis.
He wants to be the moderate candidate, the moderate Democrat.
He's going to continue to use the world Democrat, even when he's running a Democrat who won the primary.
My question is: where are the real Democrats?
Why don't they say Lieberman, you got to get out.
You lost.
You got to play by the rules.
Well, Julianne, I heard you step in there for a second.
Do you see any similarities, commonalities between the losses of Lieberman and McKinney?
I do.
I don't have an I word except for the fact that I am the iconoclast here.
But I think that…
(Soundbite of laughter)
Wait a minute.
But I think the issue of commonality, Tony, is neither of them managed to maintain engagement with their base.
I think that Lieberman, as Michael says, did believe his own press clips.
He missed being vice president, or maybe was vice president, by a few thousand votes.
But by and large, he had not engaged his base.
Moderate, Connecticut Democrats were angry about Iraq.
We are spending so much money and people are upset.
Cynthia McKinney, I disagree with everything that Michael has said about her, and quite frankly, consider her a shero.
But the fact is that she had not engaged in conversations with her base.
Also, in the primary stage before this runoff, she missed several debates.
And so she basically exhibited an arrogant attitude that basically spilled over.
Now let's play off the fact that the Republicans were all up in her Kool-Aid, including encouraging people to crossover.
That there is probably some chicanery with voting machines.
Yesterday morning, her name did not appear on the ballots, and several…
Oh no, not again.
Not again.
But it didn't.
Here name didn't appear on the ballots, Michael, in at least three precincts…
Yeah, yeah.
Write her in.
In at least three…
She's an incumbent.
People know who she is.
You can laugh about it if you want to.
Come on, Julianne.
Her name is supposed to appear on the ballot.
You laugh if you want to, but that is what you call chicanery.
I mean, she lost - the margin is so overwhelming…
No, the margin is so overwhelming that you cannot parse that, but you do have to look at some of that.
But I think both of them, what they had in common is that they failed to maintain a connection with their constituency.
So that, you know, Democrats tend to be very forgiving, especially in this potential - this current environment.
The Democrats are flailing around trying to find articulation for our dissatisfaction.
I mean, Nancy Pelosi has come up with a six-point plan that no on is excited about, but there's a lot of wiggle room if you engage your base.
Neither Lieberman nor McKinney did that.
Now the question is whether or not - I'm going to put this to you, Laura - whether or not we are, in fact, looking at another 1994 - the last time that the Congress switched parties.
Is that going to happen this time?

Well, there seems to be indications - that poll I mentioned earlier - just seems to indicate that there's a similar mood in terms of dissatisfaction on both sides of the fence, Democrats and Republicans, to what you saw in 1994.

But I happen to think that these two examples, Lieberman and McKinney, are - I don't see a lot of commonalities, and I don't think they're necessarily bellwethers for what's going to happen in November.
I think in the case of Lieberman, what used to be an advantage for him - being seeing as a moderate, being seen as a bipartisan-type legislator - is working against him now.
You know, he was seen on camera kissing George Bush last year.
Now he says it was an embrace - whatever you want to call it.
He and George Bush was kissing each other, okay.
This is not a great image to have for someone who wants to be perceived as a loyal Democrat.
And then when he gets into trouble, and he didn't see the trouble coming, as Michael points out - seasoned incumbents are way too complacent.
They're the last to know when they're in trouble.
When the trouble did come, then he said well, look, I'm going to run as an independent.
What a stupid, terrible mistake.
I think he's being punished for not being perceived as a loyal Democrat, not being perceived as somebody who is really plugging for his party.
Iraq is a problem, but that's just part of it.
In the case of Cynthia McKinney, I just think she's embarrassed her base and the folks outside her base.
And I think that this…
I think she embarrassed herself…
…is her second time around doing that - it's her second time around doing that.
Even her own campaign spokesperson said, look, you know, we lost people - we lost some of our own folks.
And we had Republicans crossing over and we have white folks who never voted in these races before voting against us.
And I think that's what did her in.
All right.
Let's move on to another topic.
Ward Connerly - I know he's one of your favorites - known for his push to ban some affirmative…
Who you talking to, Tony?
Yeah, really.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Not that iconoclastic if they're (unintelligible).
I'm just going to leave that out there for you guys to consider.
Ward Connerly…
You can have him, Laura.
No thanks.
…known for his push to…
(Soundbite of laughter)
…ban some affirmative action programs in Michigan, as you probably know, is coming under fire for receiving an annual $1 million in payments from his two tax-exempt nonprofit organizations.
Apparently, John Conyers from Michigan, Charlie Rangel, want the IRS to look into whether Connerly's pay violates the federal tax code against excessive compensation from nonprofit organizations.
So here's my question to you all: this is a shot across the bow, so to speak.
But other than potentially hurting Connerly - if it even does that - what impact do you think this can really have on the large issue?

Well, my thought is when I heard about and read about the $1 million salary or compensation, compared to my salary, I remember that song -I'm just your average, ordinary, everyday superhero trying to save the world but never really sure.
Look, with a $1 million compensation salary package, I could indeed change the world.
But, you know, this issue of the IRS - it's not just an IRS issue in terms of overcompensation, but it's also a state issue.
Not-for-profits are regulated by the state.
In New York, it's regulated by the attorney general.
And my question is why is the chairman of the board - which it should be a lay position - receiving a salary?
Board members, except for the CEO, are not supposed to draw compensation for their service - and that's what it is - service on a not-for-profit board.
I think that a million dollars is really excessive.
Whether you call it a salary, whether you call it expenses, whether you talk about being a consultant - there is something fishy here.
I mean, this is not a large not-for-profit.
This is not the Red Cross.
And so…
Yeah, but Michael…
Michael Meyers, there's been something fishy about Ward Connelly for as long as he has been drawing breath.
In fairness to…
